Sylvain Calvier calls himself a misfit, a man ''on the margins.'' Bearded, rumpled, of an indeterminate age, he once owned a shop that sold antiquities, Renaissance furniture and modern art, before it went bust years ago.
''I left with 10 francs in my pocket,'' said Mr. Calvier, below. In the years since, he has reinvented himself as a dealer in vintage photographs.
Since 2001, he has run Des Photographies in Village St.-Paul, a cluster of galleries and antiques and furnishings shops in the Marais.

His shop is hidden behind an arched passageway in a 17th-century building at the back of a cobblestone courtyard. Unlike galleries whose upscale haughtiness can scare away amateurs, Des Photographies beckons with informality and orderly chaos.

Visitors to the small space are greeted with the smell of old paper and the visual richness of the collection. Some 60,000 photographs, dating from the 1840s through the 1960s, are crammed into folders, portfolios and old wooden file cabinets.

They are grouped according to subject: artists, landscapes, portraits, travel, hats, bathing suits, circus, dance, cooking, marriages, diplomats, police. A file named ''women with problems'' contains news photographs of female trial witnesses, defendants, convicts and others with questionable reputations.
Unframed photos line a rotating gallery space on one wall, among them a Bruce Davidson image of Marilyn Monroe with Simone Signoret (4,000 euros, or $5,480 at $1.37 to the euro).

Two trays with hundreds of small, anonymous photographs lure customers who long to own a piece of French history at a more modest price. A 1930s photo of the Place de la Madeleine is 30 euros; a view of the Pont des Arts goes for 75 euros.
The most expensive item is a 20,000-euro daguerreotype of a family at a chateau after a day of hunting.

One of Mr. Calvier's favorites is a posed photo of Henri Toulouse-Lautrec at his easel in a courtyard, painting the portrait of a young woman. A handwritten note on the back dates it at 1893 or 1894. The price? Between 15,000 and 20,000 euros -- if, Mr. Calvier says, he can bear to part with it.
